title: Temporal trends (1990 - 2000) in the concentration of cadmium, lead and mercury in mosses across Europe
abstract:
Abstract\ud
The European heavy metals in mosses survey provides data on the concentration of 10 heavy metals in naturally growing mosses. The survey has been repeated at five-yearly intervals and in this paper we report on the temporal trends in the concentration of cadmium, lead and mercury between 1990 and 2000. Metal- and country-specific temporal trends were observed. In general, the concentration of lead and cadmium in mosses decreased between 1990 and 2000; the decline was higher for lead than cadmium. For mercury not enough data were available to establish temporal trends between 1990 and 1995, but between 1995 and 2000 the mercury concentration in mosses did not change across Europe. The observed temporal trends for the concentrations in mosses were similar to the trends reported for the modelled total deposition of cadmium, lead and mercury in Europe

Abstract 24 
 25 
The European heavy metals in mosses survey provides data on the concentration 26 
of ten heavy metals in naturally growing mosses. The survey has been repeated at five-27 
yearly intervals and in this paper we report on the temporal trends in the concentration 28 
of cadmium, lead and mercury between 1990 and 2000. Metal- and country-specific 29 
temporal trends were observed. In general, the concentration of lead and cadmium in 30 
mosses decreased between 1990 and 2000; the decline was higher for lead than 31 
cadmium. For mercury not enough data were available to establish temporal trends 32 
between 1990 and 1995, but between 1995 and 2000 the mercury concentration in 33 
mosses did not change across Europe. The observed temporal trends for the 34 
concentrations in mosses were similar to the trends reported for the modelled total 35 
deposition of cadmium, lead and mercury in Europe. 36 
 37 
Keywords: biomonitoring, EMEP maps, heavy metals, metal deposition, moss survey 38 
 39 
Capsule: Across Europe cadmium and lead concentrations in mosses declined but 40 
mercury concentrations did not change between 1990 and 2000. 41 
 42 
1. Introduction 43 
 44 
The heavy metals in mosses survey was originally established in 1980 as a joint 45 
Danish-Swedish initiative. The idea of using mosses to measure atmospheric heavy 46 
metal deposition was developed in the late 1960s by Rühling and Tyler (1968). It is 47 
based on the fact that mosses, especially the carpet-forming species, obtain most of their 48 
 3 
nutrients directly from precipitation and dry deposition; there is little uptake of metals 49 
from the substrate. The technique of moss analysis provides a surrogate, time-integrated 50 
measure of the spatial patterns of heavy metal deposition from the atmosphere to 51 
terrestrial systems. It is easier and cheaper than conventional precipitation analysis as it 52 
avoids the need for deploying large numbers of precipitation collectors with an 53 
associated long-term programme of routine sample collection and analysis. Therefore, a 54 
much higher sampling density can be achieved than with conventional precipitation 55 
analysis. The higher trace element concentrations in mosses compared to rain water 56 
makes analysis more straightforward and less prone to contamination. Although the 57 
heavy metal concentration in mosses provides no direct quantitative measurement of 58 
deposition, this information can be derived by using regression approaches relating the 59 
results from moss surveys to precipitation monitoring data (e.g. Berg and Steinnes, 60 
1997; Berg et al., 2003). 61 
The moss survey has been repeated at five-yearly intervals and the number of 62 
participating European countries has expanded greatly since 1990 (Buse et al., 2003; 63 
Rühling, 1994; Rühling and Steinnes, 1998). Currently, the 2005/2006 moss survey is 64 
being conducted in 32 countries, analysing moss samples from over 7 000 sites across 65 
Europe. For the first time the majority of countries (18) will also determine the nitrogen 66 
concentration in mosses (ca. 3 200 sites). A pilot study for selected Scandinavian 67 
countries has shown that there was a good linear relationship between the total nitrogen 68 
concentration in mosses and atmospheric nitrogen deposition rates (Harmens et al., 69 
2005). During 2001, responsibility for the coordination of the moss survey was handed 70 
over from the Nordic Working Group on Monitoring and Data, Nordic Council of 71 
Ministers, to the UNECE ICP Vegetation (United Nations Economic Commission for 72 
Europe International Cooperative Programme on Effects of Air Pollution on Natural 73 
 4 
Vegetation and Crops) Coordination Centre at the Centre for Ecology and Hydrology 74 
(CEH) Bangor, UK. 75 
The UNECE ICP Vegetation was established in the late 1980s to consider the 76 
science for quantifying damage to plants by air pollutants. It is one of seven ICPs and 77 
Task Forces that report to the Working Group on Effects of the Long-Range 78 
Transboundary Air Pollution (LRTAP) Convention on the effects of atmospheric 79 
pollutants on different components of the environment (e.g. forests, fresh waters, 80 
buildings) and human health (Working Group on Effects, 2004). The objectives of the 81 
ICP Vegetation (Harmens et al., 2006) are designed to meet the requirements of the 82 
LRTAP Convention, particularly at present the need to provide information for the 83 
review of the 1999 Gothenburg Protocol to abate acidification, eutrophication, ground-84 
level ozone, and the 1998 Aarhus Protocol on heavy metals. The latter was the first 85 
Protocol for the control of emissions of heavy metals; cadmium, lead and mercury 86 
emissions were targeted as they are the most toxic. 87 
The European moss survey provides data on concentrations of ten heavy metals 88 
(As, Cd, Cr, Cu, Fe, Hg, Ni, Pb, V, Zn) in naturally growing mosses (Buse et al., 2003; 89 
Rühling, 1994; Rühling and Steinnes, 1998). The main purpose of the survey is a) to 90 
provide, in the form of maps, spatial information on the distribution of heavy metal 91 
concentrations in mosses in Europe, b) identify main polluted areas, and c) develop the 92 
understanding of long-range transboundary pollution. In general, there was a clear 93 
east/west decrease in the concentration of heavy metals in mosses, related in particular 94 
to industry. Former industrial or historic sites of heavy metal pollution (e.g. mines) 95 
accounted for the location of some high concentrations of heavy metals in mosses in 96 
areas without contemporary industries. Long-range transboundary transport appears to 97 
account for elevated concentrations of heavy metals in areas without emission sources 98 
 5 
(e.g. in Scandinavia). Many contributors to the survey have reported their national data 99 
in greater detail elsewhere.  100 
 In this paper, we report on the temporal trends (1990 – 2000) of heavy metal 101 
concentrations in mosses for the heavy metals targeted by the Aarhus Protocol, i.e. 102 
cadmium, lead and mercury. As the emissions of these heavy metals have declined 103 
across Europe in recent decades (Ilyin et al., 2005), we hypothesize that the 104 
concentrations of these metals in mosses have declined too. In particular we expected a 105 
marked decline in the lead concentrations in mosses due to the introduction of unleaded 106 
petrol. The reduction in mercury concentrations is likely to be lower due to the lower 107 
reduction in emissions and hemispheric transport of mercury across the globe. The 108 
trends in the metal concentrations in mosses were compared with those reported by 109 
EMEP (Co-operative programme for monitoring and evaluation of the long-range 110 
transmission of air pollutants in Europe) regarding the modelled deposition of these 111 
metals across Europe (Ilyin et al., 2005). In a following paper we will report on the 112 
temporal trends of the other heavy metals. 113 
 114 
2. Materials and methods 115 
 116 
Moss samples were collected across Europe in 1990/1991 (Rühling, 1994), 117 
1995/1996 (Rühling and Steinnes, 1998) and 2000/2001 (Buse et al., 2003; Harmens et 118 
al., 2004). Throughout the paper we refer to the years of moss survey as 1990, 1995 and 119 
2000 respectively. The carpet-forming mosses Pleurozium schreberi and Hylocomium 120 
splendens were the preferred species for analysis. Where necessary, other species were 121 
collected, Hypnum cupressiforme being the next choice. Because the mosses were 122 
collected in a range of habitats from the sub-arctic climate of northern Sweden to the 123 
 6 
hot and dry climate of parts of southern Italy, it was inevitable that a wide range of 124 
moss species were sampled (Buse et al., 2003; Harmens et al., 2004). The moss 125 
sampling procedure was according to the guidelines described in Rühling (1994) and 126 
Rühling and Steinnes (1998) and was described in more detail in the protocol for the 127 
2000 survey (ICP Vegetation, 2001). Only the last three years’ growth of moss material 128 
was used for the analyses. The concentration of cadmium, lead and mercury were 129 
determined by a range of analytical techniques, under the broad headings of atomic 130 
absorption spectrometry, inductively coupled plasma spectrometry (both ICP optical 131 
emission spectrometry and ICP mass spectrometry), atomic fluorescence spectrometry, 132 
and neutron activation analysis. All metal concentrations were expressed as mg kg-1 dry 133 
weight at 40 oC. For details on the methods and quality control procedures we refer to 134 
the reports of the individual surveys (Buse et al., 2003; Rühling, 1994; Rühling and 135 
Steinnes, 1998). EMEP maps were produced according to the method described by 136 
Buse et al. (2003); they show the mean concentration of each metal within individual 137 
EMEP grid squares (50 km x 50 km). Please note that the designations employed and 138 
the presentation of material in this paper do not imply the expression of any opinion 139 
whatsoever on the part of the United Nations concerning the legal status of any country, 140 
territory, city or area or of its authorities, or concerning the delimitation of its frontiers 141 
or boundaries. 142 
Statistical analysis of the temporal trends (1990 – 2000) across Europe was 143 
performed by calculating the geometric mean values per metal per survey year for each 144 
country. Subsequently, a general linear model ANOVA (Minitab version 14) was 145 
applied to each metal using only the geometric mean values for the countries which had 146 
determined the heavy metal concentration in mosses in all survey years for that metal. 147 
The geometric mean values were analysed with country as a factor, year as covariate 148 
 7 
and the number of samples as weights. Weighting was applied to take into account the 149 
accuracy of the calculated geometric means (i.e. the density of sampling varied between 150 
countries; see Buse et al., 2003) and to give more weight to larger countries and less to 151 
smaller ones. For mercury changes with time were determined for the period 1995 – 152 
2000 as only two countries had determined the mercury concentration in mosses in 153 
1990.  154 
 155 
3. Results 156 
 157 
In tables 1 - 3 we only included the data for countries that determined heavy 158 
metal concentrations in mosses in at least two of the three surveys. In general, the 159 
cadmium and lead concentrations in mosses decreased between 1990 and 2000 (Tables 160 
1 and 2; Figs. 1 and 2) and in the majority of countries the mercury concentration in 161 
mosses decreased between 1995 and 2000 (Table 3; Fig. 3). The average median value 162 
for countries that had determined cadmium and lead concentrations in mosses in both 163 
1990 and 2000, decreased by 42% and 57% for cadmium and lead respectively (Table 164 
4). Analysis of the geometric mean values confirmed that the decline in cadmium and 165 
lead concentration in mosses with time was significant (Table 5). However, it should be 166 
noted that country-specific trends were found (Tables 1 - 3). In some countries, 167 
cadmium and/or lead concentrations did not change or increase between 1990 and 1995, 168 
whereas in others they did not change or increase between 1995 and 2000. However, 169 
only in Portugal the cadmium concentration was higher in 2000 than 1990 and only in 170 
Lithuania and the Russian Federation (region of St. Petersburg) the lead concentration 171 
was higher in 2000 than 1990. This appears to be primarily due to the relatively low 172 
concentration of cadmium and lead found in the mosses in the 1990 survey in those 173 
 8 
countries, possibly due to analytical error. The extremely high cadmium concentration 174 
in mosses in the Netherlands in 1995 (and to a lesser extent in 1990) also suggests an 175 
analytical error. The mercury concentration in mosses did not change in Austria and 176 
Italy and even increased in France, Lithuania, and Slovakia between 1995 and 2000. 177 
The sharp decline in the mercury concentration in mosses in Sweden is exceptional 178 
compared with the trends observed in neighbouring countries and the rest of Europe. 179 
The average median value for countries that determined mercury concentrations in 180 
mosses in both 1995 and 2000 decreased by 8%. Analysis of the geometric mean values 181 
shows that this decline with time was not significant (Table 5). 182 
Similar trends were reported by EMEP Meteorological Synthesizing Centre - 183 
East (EMEP/MSC-E) regarding the modelled total heavy metal deposition in Europe 184 
(Ilyin et al., 2005). Between 1990 and 2000 the total deposition of cadmium and lead 185 
was reduced by 45% and 52% respectively, whereas the total deposition of mercury was 186 
reduced by 8% between 1995 and 2000 (Table 4). As in the moss survey, country-187 
specific temporal trends were observed in the modelled total heavy metal deposition.  188 
 189 
4. Discussion 190 
 191 
The cadmium and lead concentration in mosses decreased significantly across 192 
Europe between 1990 and 2000, with the decline being higher for lead than cadmium. 193 
In contrast, no significant change was observed for the mercury concentration in mosses 194 
between 1995 and 2000. However, it should be noted that country-specific trends were 195 
observed. These findings are in agreement with the temporal trends reported by EMEP 196 
regarding the modelled total deposition of these metals in Europe (Ilyin et al., 2005). 197 
The modelled concentrations of cadmium, lead and mercury in air and precipitation 198 
 9 
were generally in good agreement with available measurement data in the EMEP 199 
monitoring network (Ilyin and Travnikov, 2005).  200 
Gasoline lead additives have been the key emission source of lead over the last 201 
decades. Phasing out leaded petrol across Europe has resulted in about 8 and 6 times 202 
reduction in lead emissions and depositions respectively between 1980 and 2000 (Ilyin 203 
et al., 2004). The highest reduction of emissions and depositions occurred between 1985 204 
and 1990. Whereas in 1990 the sector ‘road transportation’ was the major source of lead 205 
emission (85%), in 2003 the sector ‘metal production’ was the major source with a 206 
contribution to lead emission of 28% (Verstreng et al., 2005). The increase in lead 207 
concentration in mosses in countries such as the Russian Federation and the Ukraine is 208 
likely due to the fact that these countries still used leaded petrol long after it had been 209 
phased out elsewhere in Europe, together with an immense rise in the number of cars in 210 
these countries.  211 
Atmospheric cadmium may originate from multiple sources. Of key significance 212 
are various combustion processes based on fossil fuels (in particular coal and oil), as 213 
well as various processes in the pyrometallurgical non-ferrous metal industries and 214 
waste incineration. Whereas in 1990 the sector ‘waste incineration’ was the major 215 
source of cadmium emission (20%), in 2003 the sector ‘metal production’ was the 216 
major source (26%) (Verstreng et al., 2005). Cadmium emissions and depositions in 217 
Europe decreased about 4 and 3 times respectively between 1980 and 2000 and as for 218 
lead the highest decline was observed between 1985 and 1990 (Ilyin et al., 2004).  219 
The most important anthropogenic sources of mercury are the combustion of 220 
fuels (in particular coal), waste incineration and chlor-alkali and cement production. In 221 
1990 the maximum contribution to the total mercury emissions was from the sector 222 
‘public electricity and heat production’ (29%), but in 2003 the sector ‘other, 223 
 10 
manufacturing industries and construction’ became the largest source of emissions 224 
(31%) (Verstreng et al., 2005). Anthropogenic mercury emissions and depositions in 225 
Europe decreased about 2 and 1.5 times respectively between 1990 and 2000, with the 226 
decline being higher in the early than late 1990s (Ilyin et al., 2004). In contrast to 227 
cadmium and lead, mercury is a global pollutant, i.e. it can be transported by 228 
atmospheric flows around the world. Therefore, mercury emission sources located in 229 
other continents significantly affect mercury pollution levels in Europe. In addition, 230 
natural emission sources and re-emission contribute significantly to mercury levels in 231 
the atmosphere (Ilyin et al., 2004). 232 
The similarity in temporal trends reported for the data of the European moss 233 
survey and the modelled total depositions suggests that at the European scale these 234 
trends are not affected by potential confounding factors. For example, high uncertainties 235 
are associated with the available official estimates of anthropogenic emissions, which 236 
form the basis of the EMEP modelled deposition data. The official emission data cannot 237 
explain measured wet deposition levels of cadmium and lead in Europe (Ilyin and 238 
Travnikov, 2005). Based on the measurement data in the EMEP monitoring network, 239 
the official emission data for cadmium and lead are expected to underestimate emissions 240 
by a factor 2 to 3. In the current study, the temporal trends of the lead and cadmium 241 
concentrations in mosses were therefore compared with EMEP modelled total 242 
deposition data based on adjusted emission scenarios (Ilyin and Travnikov, 2005; Ilyin 243 
et al., 2005).  244 
Several studies have indicated that the use of mosses as biomonitors of 245 
atmospheric heavy metal deposition could be confounded by various climatic, 246 
geographical and environmental factors (e.g. Berg and Steinnes, 1997; Zechmeister et 247 
al., 2003). Confounding factors in relating the heavy metal concentrations in mosses to 248 
 11 
measured wet deposition rates across Europe include the distance of the sampling site to 249 
the sea and the significantly higher dry deposition in Central Europe, which in many 250 
cases affected the concentration in mosses more than the wet deposition (Berg et al., 251 
2003). The drier climate in Mediterranean areas at low altitude is likely to reduce moss 252 
growth rates (e.g. Vitt, 1990) in comparison with the wetter climates in northern 253 
European countries or higher altitudes. Variation in moss growth rates due to variation 254 
in (micro)climate might influence the heavy metal concentration in mosses (e.g. Gerdol 255 
et al., 2002; Zechmeister, 1998), in particular for extracellular bound elements (Gerdol 256 
et al., 2002). Conflicting results have been reported regarding seasonal variations in the 257 
heavy metal concentrations in mosses (Berg and Steinnes, 1997; Thöni, 1996; 258 
Zechmeister et al., 2003) and the variation of heavy metal concentrations in mosses with 259 
altitude (Gerdol et al., 2002; Zechmeister, 1995). How these potential confounding 260 
factors together exactly affect both the spatial and temporal variation of the 261 
concentration of various heavy metals in mosses at the European scale requires further 262 
investigation. One should bear in mind that the metal concentrations in mosses are 263 
determined over a three-year growth period, representing climatic conditions averaged 264 
over three years. A preliminary analysis by Büker et al. (2003) showed that the variation 265 
in the concentration of heavy metals in mosses in the 2000/2001 moss survey could 266 
hardly be explained by variation in climatic and geographical factors. In addition, 267 
despite the broad variation in climate between northern and southern Europe, results of 268 
the European moss surveys do not indicate a clear north – south gradient in the heavy 269 
metal concentration in mosses in contrast to a clear east – west gradient related to 270 
sources of heavy metal pollution (Buse et al., 2003).  271 
Another potential confounding factor regarding temporal trends could be that 272 
often participants have not consistently sampled mosses from the same sites in every 273 
 12 
survey and sometimes have sampled different moss species in different years. It is 274 
known that different moss species accumulate heavy metals at different rates and that 275 
the difference in accumulation rates are metal-specific (e.g. Ashmore et al., 2000; Berg 276 
and Steinnes, 1997; Galsomiès et al., 1999; Thöni, 1996). However, statistical analyses 277 
and the use of artificial neural networks indicate that the variation in heavy metal 278 
concentrations in mosses in the 2000 European survey can hardly be explained by the 279 
use of different moss species (Büker et al., 2003). Reimann et al. (2001) concluded that 280 
for regional mapping purposes the moss species H. splendens and P. schreberi can be 281 
combined without interspecies calibration, as for the majority of heavy metals the 282 
within-catchment variation is large for both moss species. Thöni (1996) came to a 283 
similar conclusion for the moss species H. splendens, P. schreberi and H. 284 
cupressiforme.  285 
The use of different analytical techniques could be another source of variation in 286 
the heavy metal concentration in mosses, but intercalibrations between the laboratories 287 
in the 1995 survey showed that there is a reasonable agreement between all analytical 288 
techniques used (Steinnes et al., 1997). However, instrumental neutron activation 289 
analysis (INAA) showed higher concentrations in some cases due to the fact that the 290 
method determines the total concentration of elements, while other methods need wet 291 
digestion of samples with nitric acid, i.e. silicate minerals in the mosses are only partly 292 
decomposed (Schaug et al., 1990). Büker et al. (2003) showed that the variation in 293 
heavy metal concentrations in the 2000 moss survey cannot be explained by the use of 294 
different analytical techniques.  295 
Although calibration factors have been developed in for example the Nordic 296 
countries to convert heavy metal concentrations in mosses to bulk wet deposition values 297 
for certain heavy metals (Berg and Steinnes, 1997; Berg et al., 2003), these models 298 
 13 
should only be used for background sites. A good linear relationship (correlation 299 
coefficient R = 0.91) was found between lead concentrations in mosses and modelled 300 
total lead deposition rates for selected grid cells in Scandinavia where EMEP 301 
monitoring stations are situated, i.e. at locations influenced by long-range transboundary 302 
air pollution only. The correlation coefficient was much lower (R = 0.56) when this 303 
relationship was determined for the whole of Europe, which is due to the fact that lead 304 
concentrations in mosses were also determined in areas of Europe affected by local 305 
pollution sources (Ilyin and Travnikov, 2005). The country-specific relationships 306 
between the heavy metal concentrations in mosses and the modelled atmospheric 307 
deposition rates require further investigation to establish in more detail any confounding 308 
factors affecting these relationships. In light of the high uncertainties currently 309 
associated with the EMEP modelled heavy metal deposition data, the data of the heavy 310 
metals in mosses biomonitoring network remain an invaluable resource for i) 311 
determining both general and more detailed spatial and temporal trends in heavy metal 312 
deposition in Europe and ii) verifying the performance of the EMEP heavy metal 313 
deposition model, at least in areas influenced by long-range transboundary air pollution 314 
only. Whereas the European moss survey provides data on ten heavy metals, detailed 315 
application of the EMEP heavy metal deposition model has been limited so far to the 316 
heavy metals cadmium, lead and mercury, although pilot calculations of atmospheric 317 
transport and depositions of other metals have been conducted recently (Ilyin et al., 318 
2006).  319 
 320 
5. Conclusions 321 
 322 
 14 
Mosses provide a cheap and effective method for monitoring temporal trends in 323 
heavy metal pollution in Europe. Temporal trends in the concentrations of cadmium, 324 
lead and mercury in mosses were in agreement with those reported for modelled total 325 
deposition of these metals in Europe. Significant reductions in the emissions of 326 
cadmium and lead between 1990 and 2000 have resulted in a significant reduction of the 327 
accumulation of both metals in mosses. The smaller reductions in emissions of mercury 328 
over the shorter time period (1995 – 2000) studied here meant that no significant 329 
changes were found in the accumulation of mercury in mosses between 1995 and 2000. 330
